On Sunday 09 March 2003 05.19, Mark Nottingham wrote:
> Hmm, the bug I opened against Apache re: automatically generating
> Content-Location in mod_dir (i.e., when "/" is rewritten to "/index.html")
> was closed prematurely; I reopened it, but it may be helpful if people
> vote for this RESTful (in my eyes, at least) behaviour...
>
> http://nagoya.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=11580

Just some quick notes regarding the caching reasoning in the bug:

A cache cannot assume an url derived from content-location can be used by
subsequent requests because content-location is not valid in the scope the
cache is interested in. Simple examples:

1) If get / -> content-location=/secure/index.html and /secure/index.html lies 
within a protected security domain then the cache might fail delivering the 
correct page if it tried to retrieve it. 
2) Also if get /index.html -> content-location=index_tuesday.html a cache 
would deliver wrong document if it tried fetching it from content-location on 
a wednesday.

This is the reasons a _formal_ cache can't use this information. But this 
doesn't mean it's not usable for web-centric applications but that it doesn't
provide information a cache can depend on. The requirements for the 
information a cache can depend on must be rather strict to avoid most of the
erratical behaviour caches can introduce.

Actually the scoping of content-location is rather narrow. It's only valid 
within the request ( for the page requested ). But this suffices to make
it very useful by removing the need for a lot of the redirects todays 
web-applications is built around since it defines the base uri of the
entity requested.

I think it'd be good if apache delivered it in as many cases as reasonable 
since a lot of people tend to look at apache to see how a response 'should' 
look and if it would be used there it probably will become more widely 
adopted in both servers and browsers.
